marketNews.title: ESDM targets 239.7 million tonnes of coal DMO in 2025, up 32.2% YoY
marketNews.content: On Monday, 20 January 2025, the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources (ESDM) announced that the domestic market obligation (DMO) for coal in 2025 is targeted at 239.7 million tonnes, an increase of 32.2% compared with the 2024 target and 14.2% higher than the 2024 actual realization. The target was set based on a multilateral meeting with coal industry players and takes into account the 2025 electricity supply plan (RUPTL). The Executive Director of the Indonesian Mining Association, Hendra Sinadia, said the increase indicates the government will aim for higher domestic coal production and consumption, and called for a review of the DMO price for PLN, which has remained at US$70 per tonne for several years.

marketNews.title: Bahlil: No planned cut to nickel production in 2025, but quota limited to 60% of proposals
marketNews.content: Minister of Energy and Mineral Resources Bahlil Lahadalia said on Friday, 17 January 2025, that the government does not plan to cut nickel ore production in 2025. He explained that the government wants to balance demand with the work plan and budget (RKAB) and industry capacity to keep nickel prices stable. He illustrated that if a company proposes to produce 20 million tonnes of nickel, the government would grant permits for only 60% of that amount, with the remaining 40% to be absorbed by local entrepreneurs. Previously, Bloomberg reported in December 2024 that the government was considering reducing the nickel ore quota from 272 million tonnes in 2024 to 150 million tonnes in 2025.

marketNews.title: Bahlil: 60% of additional 71 GW power capacity 2025-2034 to come from private sector, focus on transmission for renewables
marketNews.content: On Monday, 20 January 2025, Minister Bahlil Lahadalia said that about 60% of the additional power capacity needed to reach 71 GW by 2034 will come from the private sector. The government will focus on transmission for new and renewable energy (EBT) power plants, with PLN planning to build 48,000 circuit kilometres (approximately 8,000 km) of transmission lines. The previous week, Minister of State-Owned Enterprises Erick Thohir said that 70% of the additional 71 GW capacity is expected to come from EBT. Indonesia’s total installed capacity is currently 101 GW, with EBT contributing about 15% of the energy mix.

marketNews.title: Bahlil: Government to stop gas exports to secure domestic energy supply
marketNews.content: Minister Bahlil Lahadalia announced on Monday, 20 January 2025 that the government plans to halt gas exports in order to meet the rising domestic energy demand. The national gas requirement is projected to reach 1,471 billion standard cubic metres (Bcm) in 2025 and is expected to rise to 2,659 Bcm by 2034. The government will prioritize the use of domestic gas for internal energy needs, including support for downstream industrial projects.

marketNews.title: Dadan Hindayana: Additional IDR 100 trillion needed for 82.9 million free school-lunch beneficiaries in 2025
marketNews.content: Head of the National Nutrition Agency, Dadan Hindayana, said on Friday, 17 January 2025 that President Prabowo Subianto wants to accelerate the free school-lunch program and target 82.9 million beneficiaries this year. To achieve this, the agency needs an additional budget of IDR 100 trillion, because the 2024 state budget allocated only IDR 71 trillion for 15-17.5 million beneficiaries.

marketNews.title: Indonesia welcomes WTO ruling on EU palm-oil biofuel dispute
marketNews.content: Minister of Trade Budi Santoso said that Indonesia welcomes the World Trade Organization panel decision that upheld Indonesia’s palm-oil dispute with the European Union. The ministry said the EU will be required to adjust its policy to comply with the WTO ruling, and that Indonesia will closely monitor any EU regulatory changes to meet the WTO recommendation. The dispute originated in 2019 after the EU decided that crude palm oil would not be classified as biofuel because of deforestation concerns and that its use as transport fuel will be phased out between 2023-2030. The WTO found the EU’s rationale on greenhouse-gas emissions legitimate but criticized the EU’s implementation process.

marketNews.title: DPR proposes universities and UMKMs to manage mines
marketNews.content: The House of Representatives’ Legislative Body on Monday, 20 January 2025, proposed that universities and micro-small-medium enterprises be allowed to manage mining operations. The proposal is part of the discussion of the amendment to the third amendment of Law No. 4/2009 on minerals and coal.

tickerNews.title: TOWR to acquire ~40% of DATA
tickerNews.content: Sarana Menara Nusantara (ticker TOWR) announced through its subsidiary PT Iforte Solusi Infotek (Iforte) a plan to acquire approximately 40% of the shares of Remala Abadi (ticker DATA) from Verah Wahyudi Singgih Wong and Jimmi Anka. The transaction value has not been disclosed. The share purchase agreement was signed on 23 December 2024. The purpose is business development and to strengthen the group’s position in telecommunications infrastructure. After the transaction, TOWR, via Iforte, will become the new controlling shareholder of DATA and will be required to make a mandatory tender offer. The stock closed up 0.76% on the day.

tickerNews.title: BBTN to acquire 100% of PT Bank Victoria Syariah
tickerNews.content: Bank Tabungan Negara (ticker BBTN) announced a plan to acquire 100% of PT Bank Victoria Syariah as part of the spin-off of its sharia business, BTN Syariah. The purchase price was not disclosed; financing will come from BBTN’s internal funds. The acquisition is expected to close in May 2025, with a shareholders’ meeting scheduled for 14 March 2025. PT Bank Victoria Syariah is currently owned directly about 80.2% by Victoria Investama (ticker VICO) and about 19.8% by Bank Victoria International (ticker BVIC). VICO holds roughly 44.2% of BVIC, giving VICO an indirect and direct ownership of about 89% of PT Bank Victoria Syariah. The stock closed up 0.92% on the day.

tickerNews.title: PANI marketing sales up 156% YoY in 2024, reaches target
tickerNews.content: Pantai Indah Kapuk Dua (ticker PANI) recorded marketing sales of IDR 1.34 trillion in 4Q24 (-3% QoQ, +120% YoY). The result brought total 2024 marketing sales to IDR 6.01 trillion, a 156% year-on-year increase and 100.3% of the IDR 6 trillion target. The land-parcel segment contributed 48% of total 2024 marketing sales, residential contributed 33% and commercial 19%. Subsidiary Bangun Kosambi Sukses (ticker CBDK) contributed IDR 504 billion in 4Q24 (+16% QoQ), bringing its 2024 marketing sales to IDR 2.1 trillion (-6% YoY) and 82% of the IDR 2.6 trillion target. PANI said the decline in CBDK’s 2024 marketing sales was due to residential (-21% YoY) and commercial (-69% YoY) pressures from the 12% VAT policy uncertainty and slower mortgage-rate declines.

tickerNews.title: ACES posts 7% YoY same-store sales growth in December 2024
tickerNews.content: Aspirasi Hidup Indonesia (ticker ACES) reported same-store sales growth (SSSG) of +7% YoY in December 2024 (vs. +6% YoY in November 2024 and +11.6% YoY in December 2023). The result lifted 2024 SSSG to +8.8% YoY versus +8.1% YoY in 2023, beating the management’s guidance of +8% for 2024. The highest SSSG in December 2024 was recorded in regions outside Java (+9.7% YoY), followed by Java outside Jakarta (+6.2% YoY) and Jakarta (+3.4% YoY). ACES ended 2024 with 245 stores, up from 233 in 2023, and plans to complete the transformation of all ACES stores into AZKO by the end of 1Q 2025.

tickerNews.title: HOKI signs IDR 130 billion rice-selling agreement
tickerNews.content: Buyung Poetra Sembada, President Director of HOKI, announced a rice-selling agreement worth IDR 130 billion with PT Gurih Mitra Perkasa for one year. The deal represents 9.2% of HOKI’s annualised 9-month revenue.

tickerNews.title: HUMI allocates US$39.57 million capex for 2025
tickerNews.content: Humpuss Maritim Internasional (ticker HUMI) announced an allocation of US$39.57 million (approximately IDR 645 billion at an exchange rate of IDR 16,300 per US$) for 2025 capital expenditure, down from the 2024 allocation of IDR 802.5 billion. The funds will be used to strengthen a number of vessels and operational systems. In 2025, HUMI targets to acquire ten vessels: four oil-and-chemical tankers, five tugboats, one platform-supply vessel and LNG logistics support vessels.

tickerNews.title: WIKA records IDR 20.65 trillion new contract value in 2024
tickerNews.content: Wijaya Karya (ticker WIKA) reported that the company recorded new contract value of IDR 20.65 trillion in 2024, a 29% decline year-on-year, equal to 55.8% of the 2024 target of IDR 37 trillion. The new-contract mix was 42% infrastructure and building, 32% industry, 20% energy and industrial plant, and 6% property.

tickerNews.title: SMRA acquires 51% of PT Duta Wahana Asri
tickerNews.content: Summarecon Agung (ticker SMRA) through its subsidiary PT Summarecon Property Development purchased 2.86 million shares of PT Duta Wahana Asri for IDR 2.86 million, becoming the new controlling shareholder with a 51% stake.

tickerNews.title: MTLA targets IDR 2 trillion marketing sales in 2025
tickerNews.content: Metropolitan Land (ticker MTLA) stated that it targets marketing sales of around IDR 2 trillion in 2025. The company also reported that it achieved a 2024 marketing-sales total of IDR 1.9 trillion, a 7.3% year-on-year increase.

tickerNews.title: SOLA wins IDR 417 billion chipseal road contract
tickerNews.content: Xolare RCR Energy, through its subsidiary PT Aplikasi Bitumen Indonesia, secured a chipseal-road project operation contract from PT Trubaindo Coal Mining, a subsidiary of Indo Tambangraya Megah (ticker ITMG). The contract value is approximately IDR 417 billion, of which PT Aplikasi Bitumen Indonesia’s share is about IDR 166.8 billion. The company said the contract could significantly increase its revenue.

tickerNews.title: Bahlil: No nickel production cut in 2025, but quota limited to 60% of proposals
tickerNews.content: The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources announced on Friday, 17 January 2025 that the government will not cut nickel ore production in 2025, but will limit the permitted production to 60% of any company’s proposed output, with the remaining 40% to be absorbed by local firms. The statement followed Bloomberg’s December 2024 report that the government was considering reducing the nickel ore quota from 272 million tonnes in 2024 to 150 million tonnes in 2025.

tickerNews.title: Bahlil: Private-sector-driven 60% of 71 GW power expansion 2025-2034
tickerNews.content: The Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources said on Monday, 20 January 2025 that roughly 60% of the additional power capacity needed to reach 71 GW by 2034 will be sourced from the private sector, while the government will focus on transmission for new and renewable energy (EBT) plants, with PLN planning to build 48,000 km of transmission lines (about 8,000 km). The previous week, State-Owned Enterprises Minister Erick Thohir said 70% of the additional 71 GW capacity is expected to come from EBT.

tickerNews.title: DPR proposes universities and UMKMs to manage mines
tickerNews.content: The House of Representatives’ Legislative Body on Monday, 20 January 2025 proposed that universities and micro-small-medium enterprises be allowed to manage the mining sector as part of the amendment to the third amendment of Law No 4/2009 on minerals and coal.
